abstract:
**Abstract**  
• A novel Multi-modal Time Series Analysis Model Based on Spiking Neural Network (MTSA-SNN) is proposed  
• The model integrates Pulse Encoder and Joint Learning Module to unify multi-modal temporal representations  
• Wavelet transform enhances non-stationary signal analysis capability  
• Experimental validation on three complex datasets demonstrates superior performance  

**Introduction**  
• Traditional ANNs face challenges in processing non-stationary and event-driven time series data  
• SNNs offer biological plausibility but struggle with multi-modal fusion and temporal encoding  
• MTSA-SNN addresses these limitations through innovative pulse-based architecture  
• Key contributions include joint learning functions and wavelet-enhanced temporal analysis  

**Related Work**  
• Existing methods range from ARIMA to LSTM but lack efficient temporal feature extraction  
• Multi-modal approaches using CNNs/BiLSTMs face computational complexity issues  
• SNN variants show promise but lack effective cross-modal synchronization mechanisms  
• Prior works in financial and biomedical domains motivate our joint learning framework  

**Methodology**  
• Pulse Encoder employs Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) neurons with membrane potential dynamics: $τ_m\frac{dV(t)}{dt} = -(V(t)-V_{rest}) + R·I(t)$  
• Joint Learning Module uses Fourier transform $FT(s) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \hat{S}⊙e^{-iwT}dt$ and weight allocation mechanism  
• Wavelet transform decomposes signals into LL/LH/HL/HH subbands for multi-scale analysis  
• Output layer combines residual connections with ReLU for final prediction  

**Experiment**  
• Evaluated on MIT-BIH (98.75% accuracy), ETT (MSE 0.235), and stock market datasets  
• Outperforms LSTM (MAE 2.465→0.961) and XGBoost in financial forecasting  
• Ablation studies confirm 15.6% performance gain from wavelet integration  
• Neuron activation heatmaps demonstrate enhanced multi-modal fusion efficacy  

**Conclusion**  
• MTSA-SNN establishes new state-of-the-art in multi-modal time series analysis  
• Pulse-based architecture successfully addresses temporal synchronization challenges  
• Wavelet transform significantly improves non-stationary signal processing  
• Open-source implementation enables broader adoption in event-driven applications
